questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following voice changes is seen in dysphonia plica ventricularis?

options.a: High pitched voice in adolescent boys
options.b: Hoarseness due to plication of epiglottis
options.c: Low pitched voice due to use of vestibular folds
options.d: Weak fatiguable voice in TB larynx

questions.explanation:
Dysphonia plica ventricularis is a low-pitched voice produced by the vestibular folds. It can either be due to functional voice misuse or due to organic lesions like fixation of the true 
vocal cord. It is characterized by a low-pitched, rough and strained voice. Treatment includes voice therapy and psychological counseling.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is false about spasmodic dysphonia?

options.b: May be associated with other dystonias
options.c: Abductor type produces breathy voice and adductor type produces strangulated voice
options.d: Botulinum toxin is used in treatment

questions.explanation:
Spasmodic dysphonia is not only a local laryngeal disorder. It is associated with many 
neurological conditions too. There are 2 types of spasmodic dysphonia: Adductor dysphonia • The adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to go into adduction. The 
voice becomes strained/strangled. • Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in the thyroarytenoid muscles on one or both 
sides to relieve the spasm. Abductor dysphonia • It is due to the spasm of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle and thus the glottis is kept open. • The patient gets a breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice. Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in posterior cricoarytenoid muscles. Patients 
who do not respond to toxin injection can be treated by type 1 thyroplasty or fat injection.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the ENT OPD by her father who says his daughter has lost her 
ability to speak following the death of her mother. Her comprehension is normal but she is 
mute. Which of the following statements is false about her condition?

options.b: Vocal cords fail to adduct on phonation but adduct during coughing
options.c: Aphonia is sudden and unaccompanied by laryngeal symptoms
options.d: Treatment includes reassurance of this patient

questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture represents that of functional aphonia. In this condition, vocal cords are 
normal. Functional aphonia or hysterical aphonia is mostly seen in emotionally labile females in the age 
group of 15-30 years. Aphonia is usually sudden and unaccompanied by other laryngeal 
symptoms. Treatment is to reassure the patient of normal laryngeal function and psychotherapy. 549 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A 16-year-old boy complains of being bullied in school for his high-pitched voice. A 
Gutzmann’s pressure test is done which helps you to diagnose his condition. What condition 
does he have? 542 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with a positive Gutzmann’s pressure test is suggestive of puberphonia. It is a condition seen in emotionally labile adolescent males. They continue to speak in the 
prepubertal high pitched voice. Gutzmann's pressure test is positive when pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and 
downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and produces a low tone voice. The treatment 
is speech therapy.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 45-year-old teacher comes to you with complaints of dryness, tightness, and soreness in the 
throat. He says these symptoms appear after long hours of talking in class. He is also unable 
to hold long conversations. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is his possible 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Phonasthenia is the condition seen in this patient. The clinical scenario of voice overuse and 
keyhole appearance of glottis point to this diagnosis. Here, both thyroarytenoid and inter 
arytenoid muscles are involved. Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of laryngeal muscles. This leads to a 
phonatory gap. The shape of the gap depends on the muscle involved: • Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space • Interarytenoid alone: triangular space • Both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid: keyhole appearance

questions.question:
Question 6: You perform a direct laryngoscopy procedure on a patient and notice a pseudosulcus in the 
larynx. What is this condition due to?
questions.explanation:
Laryngopharyngeal reflux is the cause of the pseudosulcus of the larynx. Pseudosulcus of vocal 
cords is a depression in the vocal cord mucosa due to chronic irritation from the reflux. Vocal Sulci: 550

questions.question:
Question 7: A 20-year-old woman presents to you with a common cold. Due to this, her voice has 
changed. Which of the following conditions does not cause a similar voice change?
questions.explanation:
Common cold leads to rhinolalia clausa. A large nasopharynx doesn't cause rhinolalia clausa but 
instead rhinolalia aperta. Rhinolalia clausa or hyponasality is a lack of nasal resonance for words that are resonated in the 
nasal cavity. Words with M, N, NG sounds like B, D, G. It is due to the blockage of the nose or 
nasopharynx. Common causes of rhinolalia clausa are: • Common cold • Nasal allergy • Nasal polypi • Nasal growth • Adenoids • Nasopharyngeal mass • Familial speech pattern.

questions.question: Question 8: What type of speech pathology will be seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Rhinolalia aperta or hypernasality of speech will be seen in this condition of cleft palate. It is seen when certain words which have little nasal resonance are resonated through the nose. 
The defect is the failure of the nasopharynx to cut off from the oropharynx or abnormal 
communication between the oral and nasal cavities. Common causes are: • Velopharyngeal insufficiency • Congenitally short soft palate • Submucous palate • Large nasopharynx • Cleft of soft palate 551 
Sold by @itachibot • Paralysis of soft palate • Post adenoidectomy • Oronasal fistula • Familial speech pattern • Habitual speech pattern. NOTE: • Clausa = Close; closed nose and nasopharynx • Aperta = Open/aperture; abnormally open nose and nasopharynx

questions.question:
Question 9: Wagner and Grossman theory is related to 544 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Wagner and Grossman hypothesis • Explains the position of the cord in recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy. • States that “The complete paralysis of the recurrent laryngeal nerve results in paramedian cord 
due to the adduction by intact cricothyroid muscle”. • Since cricothyroid is supplied by SLN, it is spared and causes mild adduction.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following nerves provide the sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal cords?
questions.explanation:
Recurrent laryngeal nerve provides the sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal cords. Above the vocal cords, the larynx is supplied by the internal laryngeal nerve- a branch of the 
superior laryngeal nerve.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve?
questions.explanation:
Cricothyroid is not supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve. It is supplied by the superior 
laryngeal nerve. All the other muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.question:
Question 12: While assisting a direct laryngoscopy procedure being done on a patient, you notice that the 
vocal cords are in a slightly abducted position. Which intrinsic muscle of the larynx is 
responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only intrinsic muscle of the larynx that causes abduction of the 
vocal cords. 552 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: 545 
Sold by @itachibot You are a junior resident in the ENT department asked to examine a patient’s larynx. The 
patient has complete paralysis of vocal cords following a total thyroidectomy procedure. What 
is the expected position of the vocal cords?
questions.explanation: Intermediate (cadaveric) position is seen in complete paralysis of the vocal cord. • This is a neutral position of the cricoarytenoid joint. • Abduction and adduction take place from this position. • It is not always seen in cadavers (misnomer).

questions.question: Question 14: What is the most common cause for bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis?
questions.explanation:
Surgical trauma is the most common cause of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis. The incidence of permanent RLN paralysis is approximately 1% to 1.5% for total thyroidectomy 
and less for near-total procedures. Note: Previously, extra laryngeal malignancies had been the most common cause which included 
lung (50%), esophagus, thyroid, and larynx.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following does not cause bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy?
questions.explanation:
Ortner's syndrome is a rare cause of left (unilateral) recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy due to 
compression by enlarged cardiac structures such as the left atrium or pulmonary artery. Causes of recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy: • Thyroid surgery • Neck trauma • Thyroid malignancy • Cervical lymphadenopathy. Though the risk of bilateral nerve involvement is much less than unilateral, it is 
possible. Depending on whether the palsy is unilateral or bilateral, findings will differ. Terminologies in vocal cord palsy: • Pure RLN palsy: abductor palsy (the only abductor, posterior cricoarytenoid is affected) • Pure SLN palsy: rare (only cricothyroid, one of the adductors and the main tensor is affected) • Complete paralysis: both SLN and RLN are involved.

questions.question: Question 16: What is the most common inflammatory cause for vocal cord palsy?
questions.explanation:
Pulmonary tuberculosis is the most common inflammatory cause of vocal cord palsy. Lesions include: • Apical 553 
Sold by @itachibot • Mediastinal scarring • Mediastinal lymph nodes.

questions.question:
Question 17: 546 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following nerves is more prone to injury, causing vocal cord paralysis?
questions.explanation:
The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to injury, causing vocal cord paralysis. The 
reasons being: • It is longer as it loops around the arch of the aorta to climb back to the larynx. • It is in association with more structures in the mediastinum. Other options: • Right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the subclavian artery and therefore it’s shorter and 
safer. • Unilateral paralysis of the superior laryngeal nerve is rare and they are usually a part of a 
combined paralysis.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 45-year-old woman has undergone a total thyroidectomy procedure and has been shifted to 
the post-op ward. 2 hours later she develops stridor and dyspnea, but her voice is normal. 
Which of the following vocal cord lesions is the most likely cause for her condition?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical picture of stridor and dyspnea with a normal voice is most likely due to 
bilateral abductor paralysis (B/L RLN injury). It is the most dangerous vocal cord lesion. All the other options will have an abnormality in the voice. Normal voice is seen only in B/L RLN 
injury. In bilateral abductor paralysis, • Both the cords lie in the median or paramedian position, the airway is inadequate causing 
dyspnea and stridor. This may lead to death if untreated. • The voice is good. • Dyspnea and stridor become worse on exertion or during an attack of acute laryngitis.

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient in the ICU is aphonic but can maintain respiration. He has a history of recurrent 
chest infections. Which of the following nerve palsies would you suspect?
questions.explanation:
The clinical presentation is that of bilateral complete palsy (SLN + RLN). Both cords are in a cadaveric position, the patient has aphonia but respiration is maintained. 
Aphonia is suggestive of bilateral complete palsy, unilateral palsy presents with hoarseness of 
voice. Sensations are lost from supraglottis (supplied by the internal branch of SLN), the patient 
will develop aspiration and multiple chest infections.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 25-year-old singer has undergone a subtotal thyroidectomy for thyroid nodules. She 
presents to you one week later with complaints of difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice 
when she tries to reach high notes. There is no difficulty in her breathing and her voice is 
otherwise normal. Paralysis of which muscle is responsible for her condition?
questions.explanation:
554 
Sold by @itachibot Paralysis of cricothyroid is responsible for the difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice. Cricothyroid is the main tensor of the vocal cords. It is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve 
(branch of the superior laryngeal nerve).
